facts.text: The 1st respondent is a municipality governed by the provisions of the Municipal Boroughs Act, Bombay Act XVIII of 1925.
The appellant is one of the 32 councillors constituting the municipality.
The last general election to the municipality took place on the 7th May 1951.
The term of the councillors was three years computed from the date of the first general meeting held after the general election, in this case the 10th July 1951.
In the meeting on 10th July 1951, the 4th and 5th respondents were elected President and Vice-President respectively for a term of three years.
The Act was amended by Bombay Act XXXV of 1954, under which the term of office of the councillors was extended from 3 to 4 years ending on the 9th July 1955.

Term of respondents 4 and 5 expired at the end of three years from 10th July 1951, creating vacancies to be filled by fresh election of President and Vice-President for the remaining period of the quadrennium.

The Collector called a special general meeting of the municipality to be held on the 30th July 1954 to elect President and Vice-President, nominating the Prant Officer (District Deputy Collector) to preside.
On 30th July 1954, the Prant Officer under instructions from the Collector adjourned the meeting to 3rd August 1954 without transacting any business.
The 3rd respondent raised a point of order against the adjournment, overruled by presiding officer.
Full strength of 32 councillors present on both 30th July and 3rd August 1954.
At meeting on 3rd August 1954, appellant raised point of order that under the Act a President could not be elected for a term less than a year.
Presiding officer overruled appellant's objection.
13 out of 32 councillors present, including appellant, walked out refusing to participate in election for less than a year.
Remaining 19 councillors elected 2nd respondent as President for remaining period of quadrennium.
Immediately after, under presidency of newly elected President (2nd respondent), another meeting for Vice-President election.
Appellant raised same point of order, overruled; 6 councillors including appellant walked out.
Remaining councillors elected 3rd respondent as Vice-President.
Appellant filed petition in Bombay High Court under Art. 226 for writ of quo warranto against 2nd and 3rd respondents.
High Court dismissed petition on 23rd August 1954, holding election not illegal.
High Court rejected leave to appeal; Supreme Court granted special leave on 3rd September 1954.
Bombay Act LIV of 1954 published on 14th October 1954, amending sec 19 retrospectively from date of Act XXXV of 1954 (11th May 1954), validating elections held between those dates.

At 3rd August meeting, presiding officer read telegraphic message from Collector: 'Government have directed to hold election of President of Gadag Municipality on 3rd August as already arranged. Hold election accordingly today without fail.'
After ruling on points of order, 13 members walked out with permission; remaining proceeded and elected unanimously.

legal_issues.text: Whether the meeting of the 3rd August 1954 had been validly held.
Whether the President and Vice-President having been elected for the remaining period of the quadrennium had been validly elected.

petitioner_arguments.text: Meeting of 3rd August 1954 invalid because: (1) not an adjourned meeting as 30th July meeting not validly adjourned; (2) not called by Collector; (3) written notice under sec 35(3) not given, served, or published.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 19, 19A, 23, 35 of Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act 1925

petitioner_arguments.text: Election of President invalid, so subsequent Vice-President election under his presidency also invalid.
Election violates sec 19(1) as term less than one year.
Amending Act LIV of 1954 not retrospective to affect pending proceedings.
Presiding officer had no power to adjourn 30th July meeting under sec 35(11) and proviso to sec 19A(2).
Walking out of 13 councillors rendered meeting infructuous; no quorum.

respondent_arguments.text: President and Vice-President could be elected for term less than one year as sec 19 subject to sec 23(1)(A).
Sec 19 as amended by Act LIV of 1954 validates elections held between Act XXXV of 1954 and Act LIV of 1954.
Presiding officer had inherent/statutory power to adjourn 30th July meeting; alternatively, 3rd August meeting treatable as fresh meeting called by Collector.
Irregularities in notice or presiding officer appointment cured by sec 57.
Appellant did not object to adjournment on 30th July, cannot object later; no prejudice to appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide adjournment power; even assuming invalid adjournment of 30th July, 3rd August meeting valid as called by Collector under instructions, all 32 councillors present and notified orally with 3 clear days notice, irregularities in service/publication directory under sec 35(3), cured by sec 57 as no prejudice (all present).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions of sec 35(3) directory; no resolution invalid if no prejudicial effect; public presence not obligatory.

court_reasoning.text: Walking out voluntary; does not render meeting invalid or affect quorum.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No suggestion of lack of quorum post-walkout.

court_reasoning.text: Sec 19 as amended by Act LIV of 1954 retrospectively validates elections from 11th May 1954 for residue term less than one year; applies to pending proceedings as clear language deems all such elections valid, no saving for litigation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature intended to apply to all cases; authorities confirm retrospective effect on pending matters if clear.

holdings.text: Meeting of 3rd August 1954 validly held despite irregularities, which were directory and non-prejudicial.
Elections of President and Vice-President valid, including for remaining quadrennium period, validated by amending Act LIV of 1954.

precedents_cited.case_name: The King v. The General Commissioners of Income-tax for Southampton Ex parte W. M. Singer
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrospective statute can affect pending proceedings if clear language used, no need for express words on pending cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mukerjee, Official Receiver v. Ramratan Kuer
precedents_cited.relevance: Retrospective amending Act applies to pending appeals if intended for all cases of description, without implied saving for litigation.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925 (Bombay Act XVIII of 1925)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs term of office, calling and procedure for election meetings, notice requirements, adjournments, curing irregularities; sec 19 amended to allow election for residue less than one year.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act XXXV of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended municipal term from 3 to 4 years, effective 11th May 1954.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Act LIV of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended sec 19 retrospectively from 11th May 1954, validating elections for residue term less than one year held until its coming into force.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ petition.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirming High Court order dismissing writ petition, holding meetings and elections valid due to directory nature of notice provisions, no prejudice, and retrospective validation by amending Act LIV of 1954.

key_quotes.text: "No resolution of a municipality deemed invalid on account of any irregularity in the service of notice upon any councillor or member provided that the proceedings of the municipality were not prejudicially affected by such irregularity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains sec 57 curing irregularities if no prejudice.

key_quotes.text: "All elections to the office of the president or vice-president, held on or after the said date and before the coming into force of this Act, shall be deemed to be valid as if this Act had been in force on the said date."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Retrospective validation under Act LIV of 1954, sec 3.

key_quotes.text: "It is the duty of courts to give full effect to the intentions of the legislature as expressed in a statute."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies applying amendment to pending case.
